Award.AbstractNarration:
With an RUI Award from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program, Professor Jeffrey L. Katz of Colby College will research the merging of the synthetically powerful carbon-carbon triple bond, with a classic organic transformation, the nucleophilic aromatic substitution (SNAr) reaction. The Katz group has found ethynyl groups to be sufficient for activating fluorobenzenes toward nucleophilic substitution. Such acetylene-activated SNAr reactions will be pursued in three areas. First, through kinetics measurements and experiments of reaction scope, students in the Katz laboratory will study the electronic nature of acetylene functional groups with respect to aromatic substitution processes. Second, acetylene-activated SNAr chemistry will be exploited for the rapid synthesis of complex heterocycles, and heterocyclic arylethynyl-substituted luminophores. Finally, acetylene-substituted SNAr reactions will be applied to the synthesis of oxacalix[4]arene macrocycles, and the formed oxacalix[4]arenes bearing acetylene groups will be studied as a new class of bifunctional molecular receptors.

This RUI award will also support students working with Professor Katz as part of a research-based mentoring program for underrepresented minority students in chemistry at Colby College. Professor Katz is the creator and Director of the Colby Research Scholars (CRS) Program, an academic-year program for minority students to pursue independent research projects with faculty in the sciences as early as their freshman year. Professor Katz also serves as co-Director of the Colby Achievement Program in the Sciences (CAPS), a summer bridge program for entering first-year students from underrepresented backgrounds. In conjunction, these programs seek to recruit and retain minority students into chemistry and other scientific disciplines. Students participating in the CRS and CAPS programs in the Katz laboratory will have active roles in the proposed research, participate in research group meetings, attend and present posters at local and national meetings, and interact academically and socially with other student-scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For over a century, organic chemists have relied on the nucleophilic aromatic substitution (SNAr) reaction as a versatile tool for the synthesis of complex chemical structures and pharmaceuticals. The SNAr reaction chemically transforms a benzene or related ring structure by replacement of an appended halogen atom with an alternative chemical species. This chemical transformation requires that the benzene ring contain one or more attached electron-withdrawing groups to stabilize the critical reaction intermediate, and a wide variety of electron-withdrawing groups have been historically investigated.

  Carbon-carbon triple bonds (alkynes) have also long been employed in synthesis due to their chemical versatility. Funding through this award has supported the PI’s research in merging the SNAr reaction with the chemistry of alkynes. The PI has studied the electron-withdrawing polarization of alkynes in the context of SNAr reactions and explored the scope of this chemical transformation. This work was the first to comprehensively explore the scope of SNAr reactions with solely ethynyl (alkyne) activating groups, a reaction type now termed acetylene-activated SNAr reaction. The utility of acetylene-activated SNAr chemistry was further demonstrated through its use as the key transformation for the efficient synthesis of large ring structures known as oxacalixarene macrocycles.

During the funded investigations, the PI was able to adapt the conditions of these acetylene-activated SNAr reactions to rapidly produce the pharmaceutically relevant ring systems indoles and benzofurans. The discovered method that produces these compound types complements and provides a metal-free alternative to existing synthetic routes. During the funding period, the PI also discovered that benzofuran formation could be conducted using water as the reaction solvent, and that the efficiency of reactions in water are often superior to equivalent reactions conducted in less benign organic solvents. The developed aqueous methodology provides a compelling “green chemistry” entry into benzofuran-type pharmacophores. 

  The PI makes the education and training of undergraduate research students a top priority. Sixteen undergraduate research students (and two postdoctoral researchers) have been supported by this award, and each of these individuals has gained knowledge of the scientific method and critical thinking skills that will benefit them in a variety of future STEM careers. Undergraduate students working with the PI are trained to be independent researchers in preparation for graduate study, as they conduct their own chemical experiments and independently use modern chemical instrumentation.

  Additionally, the PI is dedicated to the recruitment, support, and retention of students from underrepresented backgrounds studying science at Colby College. The PI serves as co-Director of the Colby Achievement Program in the Sciences (CAPS), a major recruitment and retention program at the College. During the academic year and the summer months, the PI mentors and advises a range of first generation college students, underrepresented minority students, and students from economically underserved populations that are enrolled in gateway science courses and who have declared science majors.
